channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Logging in modules with Log4perl the easy way
item.description: Screencast and article.

item.title: Stand-alone Ajax client and the Access-Control-Allow-Origin issue
item.description: Part of the Dancer series.

item.title: Stack Overflow developer survey results
item.description: 50k developers filled in the Stack Overflow developer survey; this is a summary of what they said.

item.title: A linter for prose
item.description: Like a spell checker, but this is a linter for prose, which they say is based on advice from "the world's greatest writers and editors". I haven't tried it, but I plan on running it over the documentation for my modules, to see what it says!

item.title: A template for creating open source contributor guidelines
item.description: Safia Abdalla gives plenty of good suggestions for writing contributor guidelines for open source projects.

item.title: German Perl Workshop 2016
item.description: A report from the German Perl Workshop.

item.title: Perl is not dead: It was early web novices that gave it a bad name
item.description: Curtis keeps beating on his "battle-tested" drum, that he introduced at least year's YAPC::EU. Perl may not be hip, but it's doing just fine, thankyouverymuch.

item.title: Regex /m modifier bug in Perl 5.8.8 and older
item.description: It always gives me a warm fuzzy feeling when a participant in the Pull Request Challenge fixes CPAN Testers failures. This involved changing a regular expression so it wouldn't tickle a bug in an old version of Perl.

item.title: Random contributors are great
item.description: Sawyer's experience with a drive-by contributor to his Test::Ping module, that was nothing to do with the Pull Request Challenge.

item.title: PRC 2016 - First Three Months
item.description: A very personal report from Alberto, about the first three months of 2016, with respect to the Pull Request Challenge, but also life.

item.title: Stupid perldoc-search trick
item.description: Tom shows how you can use perldoc-search to look for documentation, while excluding the current directory, so it doesn't pull in random stuff.

item.title: More refactoring adventures
item.description: Kieren takes us through some 'fun' he had refactoring a client's code, including use of his own PPIx::Refactor module.

item.title: Super Easy SSL Certs for Mojolicious Apps
item.description: Joel shows how you can use free SSL certs from Let's Encrypt with your web app, using Mojolicious.

item.title: Twitterâ€™s Early Adopters
item.description: Twitter is celebrating its first 10 years, and to celebrate Dave did some data munging on the first 100,000 twitter users, less than 13k of whom are still active.

item.title: Assembly language for Perl Programmers
item.description: A video of Bart's talk from FOSDEM, where he talks about using Assembly from within Perl 6 programs. No, really!

item.title: Perl 6 â€” Why People Are So Excited
item.description: A video of Curtis's talk at FOSDEM earlier this year. The audio for the first 3 minutes is sadly borked, but stick with it.

item.title: 2016.11 JS Fueling Up
item.description: The latest news from the Perl 6 world.

item.title: What is the Perl Core?
item.description: David explains about core modules, and points out some Linux distributions that don't ship with all the expected core modules.

item.title: P5P Mailing List Summary: March 7th-14th
item.description: I think this was the first time that Perl 5.28 was mentioned in one of these summaries!

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description: Miguel Prz (NICEPERL)'s regular lists: Great modules released last week; MetaCPAN weekly report; StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: #243 - The FOSDEM videos are out!
item.description:
You can see gorge yourself on FOSEM videos this week. I've listed just a couple of them below.

Steve Bertrand made Sawyer X happy this week, and all he had to do was submit an unexpected pull request on a module that had been gathering dust. Make someone happy today — submit a pull request!

Neil
item.dc:subject: list of tags?
